author: Matthew Wilson
title: Skier Falls Thousands Of Feet To Certain Doom, Miraculously Survives
text:
Consider it a miracle, consider a divine intervention, or maybe it's just pure dumb luck. But
a skier survived a 1,000-foot plummet after he attempted to descend South Arapaho Peak in Colorado. Fortunately, two off-duty ski patrol members were there to save him.
On Sunday, June 16, the call went out about a skier taking a fall of a very sharp drop. The Boulder County Sheriff's Office became area of the situation.
"When this call went out, it was known that this was a very serious call from the get-go. It was called out as being a 2,000-foot fall in Skywalker Couloir. And that's a known area for us in the rescue group because we not only do rescue, but we got into rescue because we are mountaineers, climbers. We like the outdoors as well. And so, we knew this was going to be a big call from the get-go," Andrew Hildner, PIO for the Rocky Mountain Rescue Group (RMRG), told
Fox News Digital.
The 47-year-old skier attempted to descend the mountain, but he ended up falling. Instead, he tumbled 1,000 to 2,000 feet down. Fortunately, two off-duty snow patrol members saw the entire thing. They put in the call to 911 that ultimately saved his life.
"Basically, when I got there, my first goal was to locate the patient. And pretty early on, I was able to see that they were actually not on the snow, but they had sled all the way to the bench of hawks. So I knew that this injury would probably be significant," Emilie Jue, an RMRG technical field team leader, described to Fox News Digital.
Skier Critically Injured
Despite the advanced terrain, authorities managed to make it to the injured skier and help them.
Officials said they also began to descend to where the injured man had stopped and were able to provide first aid. The area is considered for advanced skiers, especially late in the season.
"I mean, this is for expert skiers only. And there's not, in most cases, there's no ski patrol nearby. This patient got lucky because there were some off-duty ski patrollers that were able to help Emily. It's a very technical ski and a technical snow climb as well and
is only for advanced skiers," Hildner said.
Ultimately, emergency responders placed the skier in a full-body vacuum splint and airlifted him off the mountain. He experienced severe injuries, but he's fortunately alive. Not many people can say they fell that far.

author: @lanacionpy
title: La Nación / Sudameris y A Todo Pulmón ponen en marcha el concurso “Dibujá un Árbol”
text: El banco Sudameris y la organización A Todo Pulmón Paraguay Respira realizaron oficialmente el lanzamiento del concurso “Dibujá un Árbol”, dirigido a niños y niñas del primero al sexto grado de todo el país. El certamen busca fomentar la conciencia ecológica invitando a los más pequeños a dibujar un árbol, con la posibilidad de ganar premios relacionados con el medioambiente. Esta campaña, que ya tuvo seis ediciones exitosas entre 2010 y 2015, vuelve con tres nuevas ediciones para los años 2024, 2025 y 2026, apostando a la educación desde la niñez para promover el cuidado de los bosques, en un contexto ambiental crítico debido a los incendios en el Chaco y la deforestación. ¿En qué consiste el concurso? Niños y niñas del 1º al 6º grado podrán participar dibujando un árbol autóctono de Paraguay, del 2 al 23 de octubre de 2024. Las obras deben ser inéditas y creadas exclusivamente por los niños, sin asistencia de terceros. Podrán ser realizadas en diversos soportes como papel, cartón, madera o lienzo, utilizando herramientas como lápices, pinceles, témperas, entre otros. Los dibujos deberán ser fotografiados y cargados por mayores en la plataforma habilitada para el concurso, disponible en atodopulmon.org. Para más información sobre el concurso, pueden consultar las bases y condiciones disponibles en este link: [https://bit.ly/3TMEm47](https://bit.ly/3TMEm47). Premios El niño o niña ganador/a se llevará como premio una computadora, una impresora, un escritorio con silla que serán entregados en su hogar. Además, un viaje a la ruta de los Colosos, con su respectivo merchandising oficial, para todos los niños del grado del/la ganador/a más 5 padres designados del grado y 3 profesores designados por la institución. La premiación se realizará en la prestigiosa Cena de Gala Humberto Rubin. Con esta iniciativa, A Todo Pulmón busca sensibilizar a las familias y las instituciones sobre la importancia de los árboles y los bosques para el futuro del país. Las nuevas generaciones, a través de actividades artísticas, serán protagonistas en la preservación del medio ambiente. [Leé también: CAF realiza charla sobre gobernabilidad digital y su impacto económico](https://www.lanacion.com.py/negocios/2024/10/03/caf-realiza-charla-sobre-gobernabilidad-digital-y-su-impacto-economico/) Acerca de A Todo Pulmón Paraguay Respira Organización paraguaya que diseña, desarrolla e implementa campañas y proyectos ambientales integrales con el fin de crear conciencia, promover buenas prácticas para la producción sustentable y generar estrategias que contribuyan a mitigar los efectos del cambio climático. Implementa proyectos forestales en conjunto con personas, grupos, instituciones educativas y empresas, plantando especies nativas y exóticas en plantaciones puras o en sistemas agroforestales, enriqueciendo bosques degradados y protegiendo bosques amenazados. [Lea también: Los sobrecostos del 33 % pueden revertirse, afirman](https://www.lanacion.com.py/negocios_edicion_impresa/2024/09/25/los-sobrecostos-del-33-pueden-revertirse-afirman/) [#Sudameris](/tag/sudameris/) [#A Todo Pulmón](/tag/a-todo-pulmon/) [#conciencia ecológica](/tag/conciencia-ecologica/) [#A Todo Pulmón Paraguay Respira](/tag/a-todo-pulmon-paraguay-respira/) [#Humberto Rubin](/tag/humberto-rubin/) [#Cena de Gala](/tag/cena-de-gala/)

author: Admin
title: PMI Consultant Evolves into Universal Talk Solutions to Address Surge in Language Service Demand
text:
Florida – PMI Consultant, a cornerstone in business consulting, proudly unveils a strategic evolution to meet the evolving needs of its clientele. Bolstered by a remarkable surge in demand for language services, PMI Consultant is embarking on a forward-thinking transformation, creating a specialized division—Universal Talk Solutions—solely devoted to delivering comprehensive linguistic solutions.
The genesis of this transformative move is rooted in a substantial shift in demand dynamics. The year 2023 witnessed an unprecedented sevenfold increase in interpretation cases compared to business consulting, prompting a proactive response from PMI Consultant. Recognizing this significant trend, the company made the strategic decision to establish Universal Talk Solutions as an independent entity under the PMI umbrella.
“As PMI Consultant, we’ve always been dedicated to delivering exceptional business consulting and support to our community. The landscape changed dramatically in 2023 when we observed a sevenfold increase in demand for language services over consulting cases. This pivotal realization became the driving force behind the decision to create Universal Talk Solutions,” explains Pedro Raphael, CEO at PMI Consultant.
Effective November 2023, Universal Talk Solutions will stand as a distinct division, catering exclusively to the rising demand for translation of documents, onsite interpretation, and phone interpretation for medical and business needs. This strategic shift positions the company to better streamline and enhance the delivery of language services, acknowledging the unique challenges businesses face in today’s interconnected world.
“Universal Talk Solutions is more than a new name; it’s a reflection of our dedication to providing seamless communication solutions,” adds Pedro Raphael.
With a team of over 500 interpreters and translators, Universal Talk Solutions is well-equipped to meet the diverse and growing language requirements of its clients. The division is supported by cutting-edge technological solutions, including a proprietary CRM system, ensuring efficiency and precision in every language service provided.
“The decision to create Universal Talk Solutions was not only a response to demand but a strategic move to deliver language solutions with the same dedication and excellence our clients expect. This new division embodies our commitment to providing specialized linguistic services tailored to the evolving needs of our community,” adds Pedro Raphael.
For more information about Universal Talk Solutions and its range of language services, please visit
https://universaltalksolutions.com or contact (855) 392-2122.
About PMI Consultant:
PMI Consultant has been a reputable provider of business consulting and support services, earning trust within the community. Acknowledging the surge in demand for language services, PMI Consultant expands its offerings with the creation of Universal Talk Solutions, a dedicated division focused on specialized language services. For more information, visit
https://universaltalksolutions.com

UniversalTalk Solutions

author: Diario Al-Quds Libération
title: Franja de Gaza: 320 días de genocidio
text:
Las fuerzas de ocupación sionistas continúan cometiendo el crimen de genocidio en la Franja de Gaza, por 320º día consecutivo, lanzando decenas de ataques aéreos y bombardeos de artillería, mientras cometen masacres contra civiles, en medio de una situación humanitaria catastrófica como resultado del asedio y el desplazamiento de más del 95% de la población.
Los aviones y la artillería de ocupación continuaron sus incursiones y bombardeos violentos – hoy miércoles – en varias partes de la Franja de Gaza, apuntando a hogares, reuniones de personas desplazadas y calles, matando a decenas de mártires y heridos.
Las fuerzas de ocupación han continuado su invasión terrestre de grandes barrios de Rafah, desde el pasado 7 de mayo, y de varias zonas de Khan Yunis y Gaza, en medio de bombardeos aéreos y de artillería y cometiendo horribles masacres.
Hoy, las fuerzas de ocupación emitieron órdenes de desplazamiento a los residentes de dos plazas en Deir al-Balah, en el centro de la Franja de Gaza, que está habitada por un millón de personas desplazadas.
Un niño resultó herido como resultado de disparos aleatorios de las fuerzas de ocupación en las proximidades de la escuela Al-Mazraa, al este de la ciudad de Deir Al-Balah, en el centro de la Franja de Gaza.
Los aviones de ocupación bombardearon una casa de la familia Abu Hadros en las cercanías de la ciudad de Hamad, al oeste de Khan Yunis, lo que provocó un gran número de mártires y heridos que todavía están atrapados bajo los escombros.
Cuatro campesinos mártires fueron recuperados como resultado del bombardeo israelí al noroeste de la ciudad de Rafah, al sur de la Franja de Gaza.
Nuestro corresponsal informó que los aviones de ocupación lanzaron una incursión esta mañana contra las zonas del norte de Khan Yunis.
Los aviones de ocupación lanzaron una incursión en las cercanías de las Torres Al-Qastal, al este de Deir Al-Balah en el centro de la Franja de Gaza.
Un pescador fue martirizado y otro resultó herido por balas de las fuerzas de ocupación en la costa de Deir al-Balah, en el centro de la Franja de Gaza.
Varios ciudadanos resultaron heridos como resultado de los disparos de las fuerzas de ocupación contra las tiendas de campaña de los desplazados en Mawasi, al oeste de Rafah.
Al amanecer del miércoles, una ciudadana fue martirizada y otras seis personas resultaron heridas como resultado de la ocupación de una casa de la familia Al-Khatib en Tal Al-Zaatar, en el campo de refugiados de Jabalia, en el norte de la Franja de Gaza.
La ocupación lanzó varias incursiones al este de Deir al-Balah en el centro de la Franja de Gaza, y una incursión tuvo como objetivo un apartamento residencial en el área del proyecto Beit Lahia en el norte de la Franja de Gaza.
Los aviones de ocupación bombardearon la ciudad de Al-Qarara, al este de Khan Yunis, al sur de la Franja de Gaza.

author: Ember Peak
title: Storm Gerrit's impact: fatalities, tornado, and widespread chaos | Voice of Europe
text: Severe weather attributed to Storm Gerrit wreaked havoc across the United Kingdom, with a reported tornado in Manchester and a tragic incident in flood-hit North Yorkshire resulting in three fatalities. The deadly episode occurred when a 4×4 vehicle encountered difficulties in the River Esk near Glaisdale during the storm, [The Times reported.](https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/storm-gerrit-uk-map-tornado-manchester-weather-warnings-train-delays-3m77w9f7l) As Storm Gerrit continued its sweep, authorities issued warnings about hazardous conditions, emphasizing the risks of driving amidst the chaos. In Manchester, the tornado led to significant property damage, including roofs being torn off, while Morecambe Bay experienced the onslaught of a “supercell thunderstorm.” The emergency services responded to the incident near Glaisdale, with three men losing their lives after the submerged vehicle was recovered by the fire service. The River Esk area in North Yorkshire faced particular challenges, with roads severely affected and additional incidents of cars becoming trapped in water. Despite these dangers, one individual attempting to assist was successfully rescued. In the broader context, Storm Gerrit’s impact extended beyond North Yorkshire, causing disruptions throughout the country. The Met Office faced criticism as residents in Scotland, caught off guard by the storm’s intensity, questioned the adequacy of the initially issued yellow warnings. The aftermath included 80mph winds, blizzards, and heavy rain, with flood alerts affecting various regions, particularly in the Midlands and the north of England. Amid the chaos, Stalybridge in Tameside, Greater Manchester, bore the brunt of a T5 tornado, causing damage to around 100 homes. As the storm subsided, the Met Office committed to reviewing the efficiency of its weather alerts in the coming days, acknowledging the need for a comprehensive assessment of Storm Gerrit’s impact and response.

author: news@belfastlive.co.uk (Shauna Corr)
title: Ulster American Folk Park bog volunteer efforts spark resurgence in Irish mosses and lichen
text:
The backbreaking efforts of conservation volunteers have sparked a resurgence in Irish bog mosses and lichen at the Ulster American Folk Park.
We headed along the well trodden paths of the much-loved attraction to see them in action.
And hidden behind the old traditional farm houses and famine era thatches, the last remaining plot of raised bog in the grounds is now thriving thanks to a community effort supported by The Conservation Volunteers and Hughes Insurance.
Read more:
Belfast Council 'cut and paste' parks plans slated over nature failings
Read more:
Fermanagh's railway hopes on the line over housing plan
Used to show how Irish folks heated their homes by cutting turf until now, the plot is slowly being transformed into a carbon sink to help fight climate change.
But there is still more work to be done this month and they are calling out for help to rid the area of trees and invasive species like Rhododendron which are soaking up the ground water that could help more bog species thrive.
TCV operations leader, Diane Keys, said: “Because of industrialisation we have lost a lot of our native bogs.
“What’s important now is to start managing and recognising the value of these aas carbon sinks [and] a huge environmental treasure.
“We are removing a lot of invasive species [like].. Rhododendron, laurel and self seeded birch.
“These are all causing the bog to dry out. The roots are soaking up the absolutely invaluable moisture that is required for all these beautiful mosses and bog vegetation to grow, to thrive.
“The weight of it then compacts and eventually forms this beautiful peat. All of that is multiple layers and huge volumes of carbon which is now trapped and that’s what we want to be protecting.
“It’s so invaluable to our local environment.”
Ulster American Folk Park curator, Liam Corry, said: “From an environmental point of view... peatbogs are Ireland’s rainforest.
“There is an ecosystem there that you don’t find in many other places... they are unique.
“The bog we had here is quite small... over time it had been cut away and turned into agricultural land.”
This meant that other species starting to encroach on what was left of it.
But Liam added: “It’s great that now we have formed a partnership with the Conservation Volunteers to allow this encroachment to be taken out.
“Over time I can see a huge difference to this small patch of bog... it means the bog will survive. It’s really important because we have plants like lichen, which is really unusual.
“It was very pleasing to find it growing.”
Senior TCV project officer, Robert Arbuckle, said the work they have done so far at the Folk Park’s bog has seen the bog mosses thrive and new lichens move in.
He added: “The work that we do here is to try and improve biodiversity on the bog and getting rid of the invasive species.
“Once that’s clear it gives the habitat some time to recover.
“It will let wildlife come in and the natural flora and fauna start to rebuild again.
“Eventually, what we want to get to is a point where we can rewet these lands because they have been drained for the excavation of peat.
“The likes of lichen, when that starts showing up, we know we are doing a good job because it means there’s good air quility around here.
“The other thing we want to conserve is our Irish mosses and the wildlife that will come in as well - the likes of birds and butterflies.
“Already we were told it seems there are more birds coming in... from the work we did last year and this year.
“As soon as you clear a bit of space wildlife comes in and starts to thrive again.”
TCV volunteer, Karley Wauchope, said she decided to help because she loves being outside and being with people.
She added: “We just want the bog to be a bog. There’s no better place to be.
“It’s get us out in the fresh air, lot’s of exercise, a bit of chit chat and a laugh or two.
“Even the health and wellbeing of doing this kind of work is amazing.”
Hughes Insurance is supporting the work. Its marketing manager, Emma Haughian, told us: “Part of my job is to define an ESG strategy (Environment, Social, Governance).
“We’ve really worked hard over the past two years to clearly define what our objectives are.
“Partnering up with The Conservation Volunteers was the perfect fit for us at Hughes... to help us understand biodiveristy and make an impact in our local community... and environment.”
To find out more on TCV’s Peatland Restoration project or how to volunteer email TCVNI@tcv.org.uk with subject line ‘The Bog’ for all available dates in February 2024 to help out.
